awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Real-Time Mineral Data Collection and Identification Module
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project improves mining and geotechnical drilling activities by eliminating handling of bulky samples.  Core drilling consumes about 10,000 gallons of water per day, often in water-deficient areas. The proposed new approach negates the need for water in the drilling process, thereby mitigating the risk of pollution to public and wildlife drinking water sources. Reducing the time required for a typical drilling project from weeks to days reduces the carbon emission from the energy-intensive drilling equipment required. This solution to problems associated with acquiring subsurface data with traditional techniques has an addressable market segment value of $21 billion. The new instrument to be developed will eliminate the need for off-site lab services, core drilling, and site geologists, resulting in lower industry life cycle costs and spurring critical exploration activities for needed US strategic minerals. 

The intellectual merit of this project is based in the development of a novel drilling module that will be able to acquire subsurface chemistry and geotechnical properties of rocks and soils, to assess the type and value of minerals present both quickly and accurately. The conventional way of evaluating these materials is by core drilling, which presents various problems related to cost, sample quality and logistics. This research uses a combination of optical images, x-ray fluorescence, and gamma-ray density, as well as compressive strength data from a newly curated database that will be developed from open-source geospatial data, collections of geology and geotechnical reports, rock core databases, implicit geology modeling principles, and machine learning methods to characterize rock and soil samples. It aims to solve the technical challenges that currently prevent such a tool from being available to the industry today; these include mud smearing in the drill hole sidewalls, the high pressure and heat of the target environment, and challenges in wireless data transmission. The goal of this research is to create, validate and calibrate a method for automating the characterization of an unknown rock or soil sample in situ via a combination of hardware and software innovations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This research and development (R&D) work titled "Real-Time Mineral Data Collection and Identification Module" used machine learning and a unique sensor package to simulate real-time analysis of the walls of mineral exploration and geotechnical boreholes. Three main data types, rock image, XRF analysis, and rock strength, were combined to successfully identify rock types and report on the quality of the observed rock types in real time. This involves using sensors to capture images, chemical composition, and the sonic velocity of the rock types continuously down the drill hole. This data will reach the surface from 600 ft-1000 ft depths using a novel technique that uses high-speed acoustic communications and telemetry via solid drill pipes. Data processing occurs within the system and displays the data in standard industry file formats such as Comma Separated Values (CSV) tables and PDF log sheets that can be seamlessly integrated into major mining and construction software for further analysis. The solution was designed to cut mineral exploration and geotechnical drilling costs and environmental impacts. It will provide accurate and instantaneous results for critical decision-making in the mining and construction industries.

We demonstrated that a combination of a few sensors applied downhole is sufficient to identify and report rock types in real-time. We also demonstrated that the downhole environment could be overcome to effectively deploy the sensor package downhole without compromising data quality. The high data resolution that can be achieved is capable of logging layers that are inches thick. This will allow for the detection of thin mineralized layers of either valuable vein metals such as gold or contaminants such as clays. The high resolutions will also make differential loading of explosives in rock blasting operations possible, improving blast fragmentation and reducing environmental hazards such as excessive vibrations and fly rock. The solution is used with rotary air drilling in dry holes, the currently less desired method for mineral exploration due to physical sample quality. However, rotary air drilling is the cheapest and dry exploration holes imply no water usage. Water consumption in core drilling and reverse circulation drilling can be as much as 10,0000 gal/day of scarce water resources that may be subject to contamination by 50% of the processed water loss through cracks in the rock wall. This technology has welcome implications for the environment. Subsurface rock data acquisition at the drill site results in mineral exploration activities being shorted from months to days. Reducing diesel emissions from drill rigs in this way helps decarbonize the industry to affect the environment positively. There are several other upsides to this technology, some of which are giving technology access to a wider industry base through lower tier pricing strategy, internet interface for retrieving real-time data, dynamic hole planning to make go-no-go project decisions, and optimizing drill hole locations based on current data and being able to complete entire exploration projects remotely using new generation autonomous drill rigs. This means that efforts to uncover the nation's strategic mineral resources do not stop because of weather or harsh remote environments. The outcomes established a product-market fit because it responded to pain points in mineral exploration drilling and optimized the design to reduce cost and complexity while benefiting the environment. Our national security also relies on such technology. These factors support a Phase 2 proposal to bring the well-needed tool to the industry.

 


Last Modified: 05/03/2023
Modified by: James E Starks
